oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Elizabeth Lampert on steps of Newark Public Library.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Elizabeth Lampert on steps of Newark Public Library. The child is Elizabeth Lampert of Rochester, NY on her birthday in 1900. She was the granddaughter of Hiram Edgerton (1847-1922) a contractor and later Mayor of Rochester 1908-1922. She was the child of Edna Edgerton and Henry Lampert. Elizabeth married Russell Dingeman.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Jackson and Perkins Rose Garden
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Front has 1: - View of the famous Jackson and Perkins Rose Garden, Newark, N.Y. , 50006 printed on it. Reverse has Pub. by Wm. Jubb Co., Syracuse, N.Y. printed on it. The company's name came from the two partners who started the business, Charles H. Perkins (1840–1924) and his father-in-law, Albert E. Jackson (1807–1895). The company began in 1872 in Newark, New York as a truck farm. The Jackson & Perkins mail order business, the first mail order rose nursery in the nation, was launched after the 1939 World's Fair. The firm was eventually sold, and the growing business moved to Tustin, California.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Business & Industry;
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: postcard ; 3 inches x 5 inches (7.7 cm x 12.7 cm.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This digital image may be used for educational purposes, as long as it is not altered in any way. Prior written permission is required from the Newark Public Library for any other use of the image.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Newark High School
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Newark High School. Has accompanying information which reads: Compliments of Lettie Taylor Farrell, NHS Class of 1933, 206 Blakely Court, Newark, New York 14513-2105. Phone 315-331-1717. Intermediary: Helen Taylor A. Walker, 315-548-3400. Further accompanying information reads: Newark High School 1891-1940. Southwest corner of Church Street and East Avenue, Newark, New York. In conjunction with he All Washington School Reunion executed by the NHS Class of 1940 on the occasion of their 50th during week of July 16-22, 1990 Lettie Taylor Farrell NHS Class of 1933 commissioned Newark artist Owen Hughes to draw Washington School from a circa 1930 post card. This is a print of the original which is retained by the patroness. The historic marker on the school site, a gift of the last Washington School graduating Class of 1940, was placed on he anniversary of its graduation, June 25, 1990 and was dedicated July 21, 1990. It reads: Newark High School, School on this site by 1832, Union School 1851, Washington School 1891-1940, WW2 POW camp 1944-1946, demolished 1948. NHS Class 1940. June 25, 1990. Lettie Taylor was born about 1915.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Architecture;
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Print (visual work), 8 1/2 inches by 11 inches (22 cm x 28 cm.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This digital image may be used for educational purposes, as long as it is not altered in any way. Prior written permission is required from the Newark Public Library for any other use of the image.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Hoffman Clock Museum brochure outside view
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hoffman Clock Museum brochure outside view. Contains information about the Hoffman Clock Museum housed at the Newark Public Library. Augustus L. Hoffman (1856-1945) was a retail jeweler and a watchmaker who owned a jewelry shop in Newark, NY for 30 years. He collected watches and clocks over a period of many years. His second wife, Jennie DeVall Hoffman, collected lusterware, glassware and porcelain. In their later years the Hoffmans made arrangements to preserve their collections and make them available to the public. The trustees of the Hoffman Foundation arranged with the Newark Library to display the clock collection as well as many of Jennie Hoffman's collectibles in a new wing that had been added to the library. The formal opening took place in December of 1954.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Medicine, Science & Technology;
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Black-and-white booklet
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This digital image may be used for educational purposes, as long as it is not altered in any way. Prior written permission is required from the Newark Public Library for any other use of the image.

His second wife, Jennie DeVall Hoffman, collected lusterware, glassware and porcelain. In their later years the Hoffmans made arrangements to preserve their collections and make them available to the public. The trustees of the Hoffman Foundation arranged with the Newark Library to display the clock collection as well as many of Jennie Hoffman's collectibles in a new wing that had been added to the library. The formal opening took place in December of 1954.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: People on steps of Newark Public Library - 1
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: People on steps of Newark Public Library. The child is probably Elizabeth Lampert of Rochester, NY on her birthday in 1900. She was born October 1894. She was the granddaughter of Hiram Edgerton (1847-1922) a contractor and later Mayor of Rochester 1908-1922. She was the child of Edna Edgerton and Henry Lampert. Elizabeth married Russell Dingeman.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: People;

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: People on steps of Newark Public Library. The child is probably Elizabeth Lampert of Rochester, NY on her birthday in 1900. She was born October 1894. She was the granddaughter of Hiram Edgerton (1847-1922) a contractor and later Mayor of Rochester 1908-1922. She was the child of Edna Edgerton and Henry Lampert. Elizabeth married Russell Dingeman.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Invitation to dedication of Newark Public Library
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Invitation to dedication of Newark Public Library. Frederick Augustus Rew (10 Aug 1806-26 Feb 1880) and Sarah (Adams Stow) Rew (11 Feb 1800-14 Mar 1851) joined a party of pioneers who went further west and opened the roads to Ohio. Family tradition has it that Frederick A. Rew was the Government surveyor who laid out the city of Toledo, Ohio and the surrounding country. About 1839 they settled at Maumee , Lucas County,Ohio, but the new settlement was subject to malaria, and it was difficult to get quinine. Sarah Rew suffered so badly that the family decided to return to New York state. The journey was made by boat from Toledo to Buffalo, thence by the Erie Canal to Newark, Wayne County, New York. He was an insurance agent at Newark, Wayne County, New York in 1860. Their son, Henry Cunningham Rew (2 Apr 1839-13 Feb 1912) donated the land for the library to be built upon.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Community & Events;
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Program; 5 1/2 x 7 in; 12.7 cm x 17.7 cm
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This digital image may be used for educational purposes, as long as it is not altered in any way. Prior written permission is required from the Newark Public Library for any other use of the image.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Wing ready at library
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Unidentified newspaper clipping has information dated 9 June 1939, stating that a new adult reading room has been completed as an addition to the Newark Public Library. Mentions librarian Louise Van Duser, Charles A. Herrick, president of the library association, Mrs. T. E. Elliott, trustee; also mentions Charles A. VanBuren, architect, G. Fred Monroe, superintendent, Miss Anna Miller, secretary of the association, and Mrs. Sarah A. Allerton, who donated money for materials.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Community & Events;
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Newspaper clippings
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This digital image may be used for educational purposes, as long as it is not altered in any way. Prior written permission is required from the Newark Public Library for any other use of the image.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Obituary of John H. Slagle
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Unidentified newspaper clipping mentions the death of John H. Slagle on Feb. 20, 1980. He was the curator of the Hoffman Clock Museum in the Newark Public Library. He lived 3 Feb 1906-20 Feb 1980. See http://hoffmanclockmuseum.org/ for more data about the museum. See: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jackson_%26_Perkins for more data about that company. See http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~springport/pictures44/00004473.html, for more information about that company.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Community & Events;
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Newspaper clipping
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This digital image may be used for educational purposes, as long as it is not altered in any way. Prior written permission is required from the Newark Public Library for any other use of the image.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Obituaries and article about the Rew family
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Rew family was prominent in Newark and donated money and land for the Newark Public Library. These three articles have information about Dr. Frederick A. Rew (1836-1928) who served in the Civil War; his wife "Gussie" who moved to Buffalo with their son Frederick upon the elder man's decease; and about Henry Cunningham Rew, the donor of the funds for the Newark Public Library.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Newspaper clippings about Newark Public Library
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Unidentified newspaper clippings about the Newark Public Library. They mention the first circulating library in the village in 1834; Rev. Charles W. Tomlinson, a Universalist pastor active in the organization of the Newark Free Public Library Association; Henry Cunningham Rew, who donated the land and funds for the library; library staff (Miss Omo Mary Imhoff, Mrs. Louise VanDuser, Miss Lucille Messinger, and Mrs. Rudolph Klossner.) Also mentions the Hoffman Clock Museum inside the library.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Community & Events;
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Newspaper clippings
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This digital image may be used for educational purposes, as long as it is not altered in any way. Prior written permission is required from the Newark Public Library for any other use of the image.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Newark Banking History
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Newspaper clipping describing more of the banking history of Newark, NY. Mentions Fletcher William as Newark's first banker; he established the Bank of Newark in 1841. Mentions other employees Byron Thomas, Byron Williams, and Frank Garlock. Also mentions S. S. Peirson and Company, with its employees S. S. Peirson, E. P. Soverhill, C.H. Perkins, S. Ray Peirson, And Ernest V. Peirson. It was eventually incorporated in 1905 as Newark State Bank, with C. P H. Vary as President. Further mentions Newark State Bank, Arcadia National Bank, and First National Bank.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Community & Events;
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This digital image may be used for educational purposes, as long as it is not altered in any way. Prior written permission is required from the Newark Public Library for any other use of the image.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Donation for Newark Library
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Newspaper clipping of title of article, which reads "Builder of Cicero Gas Works Donates Funds for Newark Public Library." This is Henry Cunningham Rew, who started the Cicero Gas Work (in Illinois), to produce carbonated water-gas.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Community & Events;
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Newspaper clipping;
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This digital image may be used for educational purposes, as long as it is not altered in any way. Prior written permission is required from the Newark Public Library for any other use of the image.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Newark Postal and Banking History
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Article has information about Newark's postal service, noting that the village was incorporated on 21 July 1853. Mentions postal employees Lamar Hotchkiss, James M. Pitkin, Francis Leahy, C. G. Stratton, A. R. Taylor, Bert Mitchell, Warner Landfield, and Ford Durfee. Also mention development of local banking, with Lincoln-Rochester opening in 1934, and Columbia Bank in 1954. Also mentions the pre-1841 Bank of Geneva, and its employees Orrin Blackmar and Edson Blackmar. Refers to Imogene Russell's "Old Time Days in Newark". Further mentions C. W. Burgess and Ernest J. Darrow of the Chamber of Commerce Change Fund in the 1930's.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Community & Events;
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This digital image may be used for educational purposes, as long as it is not altered in any way. Prior written permission is required from the Newark Public Library for any other use of the image.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Newark Public Library description
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Newspaper clipping mentioning that the new building is now open to the public. Also says that it was donated by Henry C. Rew of Chicago, and describes several hundred people visiting the library. Gives detailed description of interior. Mentions Miss Imhoff (librarian) and her assistant, Mrs. Richmond. Another clipping describes the dedication ceremonies.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Community & Events;
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This digital image may be used for educational purposes, as long as it is not altered in any way. Prior written permission is required from the Newark Public Library for any other use of the image.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Newark Rejoices in New Library
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Newspaper clipping probably from early 1900s, with headline reading "Newark Rejoices in its Beautiful New Library". Mentions that Henry C. Rew, a wealthy industrialist, expended $25,000 in builing and equipping the library, which was a memorial to his parents, Frederick Augustus Rew and Sarah Adams Stowe.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Community & Events;
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: This digital image may be used for educational purposes, as long as it is not altered in any way. Prior written permission is required from the Newark Public Library for any other use of the image.
